title: Before 15 November 2020, who will be elected to be the next leader of Japan's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP)?
preds:
And we have a winner..
https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/09/0c34ef2789c5-ldp-set-to-elect-suga-as-leader-to-succeed-japan-pm-abe.html
(the article was updated 30 odd minutes ago, the URL wasn't - this is the final result)
Recent news articles have been completely devoid of any support for Ishiba, my forecast for Ishiba now drops to sub 0.5%

Updated 20200912 Further to my forecasts below, I have amended my forecast to 100% Suga based in the amount of positive news in his favour (https://s.nikkei.com/33rzSEU) and a lack of similarly positive news for the other 2 candidates. Updated 20200908 Further to my forecasts below, Suga's popularity continues to grow as the formal LDP leadership race got underway today - https://reut.rs/3h6k3Ix and - https://bit.ly/3hb9C6P. It is also clear that the only three left in the contest at this stage are Ishiba, Kishida and Suga. However, Ishiba and Kishida's popularity, both amongst public and the all important factions within the LDP are insufficient to carry them to the leadership position. Ishiba's plan to use Nintendo's Animal Crossing game to garner public suport (https://bit.ly/2ZfcBoj) has been abandoned for fear of contravening the games terms of use. Thus Suga appears the frontrunner. Hence my above revised forecast leaving a small margin for Ishiba and Kishida in the unlikely event some misfortune befalls Suga. Updated 20200904: Further to my forecast below of 2 days ago, see Asahi Simbun polls showing Suga's public accpetance - https://bit.ly/33dbozp and how Suga has overtaken Ishiba in the public poularity stakes. Suga also appears to have Abe's support - see https://bit.ly/3bEEqvD. Suga therefore seems to have all the internal LDP support required for him to become leader of LDP and hence the most likely Prime Minister to succeed Abe. Also see also https://bit.ly/330KDh9 regarding probability for Inad and Noda. 2020902:
The LDP decided a few days ago to limit the selection process to the parliamentarians and select prefecture represenatives thus avoiding an internal election amongst its 1m members. This decision allowed for a quicker appointment of Abe's replacement and the date is set for 14 Sept. (See WP - https://wapo.st/3jEK6Z1) Yoshihide Suga, a long time allay of Abe's who is fully conversant with Abe's policies and who is Chief Cabinet Secretary has receievd some backing from party heavyweights, is the most likely successor. Ishiba, who stood against Abe previously does not seem to have the support of the party heirachy, whereas Suga does. Ishiba's support comes from the broader party members and thus the decision to exclude the broader party from the vote has given Suga a boost. See also SwissInfo (SBC)- https://bit.ly/3lFX22K Two women, Noda and Inada have put their names forward (See NYT - https://nyti.ms/3gSy0Kd). Their chances are slim albeit one of Abe's policies was to promote women in polictics. Yoshihide Suga served as Abe’s Chief Cabinet Secretary and according to the tradition, he is expected to be elected by the LDP on Sept. 14.

Updating as Suga now has 58% of LDP votes, more than the majority required. The election will be on 9/14 so it's all but assured.  source: https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/japan-yoshihide-suga-in-pole-position-for-pm-as-debate-kicks-off/story-4M3r7KLtLElCi8ZGmbcyXL.html
Recent news that Suga already has a majority of votes.
Suga already has 58% of total LDP votes - more than the majority required - without even counting the additional 141 votes that will come from party prefecture chapters.
existing abe support and media polls

As my team members pointed out, Suga is nearly confirmed as the next leader of the LDP according to very recent news. 
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/09/japans-opposition-unites-as-suga-set-to-succeed-abe-as-prime-minister.html
https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/japan-yoshihide-suga-in-pole-position-for-pm-as-debate-kicks-off/story-4M3r7KLtLElCi8ZGmbcyXL.html

Thanks to @ashalom that updates me on this: Yoshihide Suga has support to become party leader from 308 - almost 80% - of ruling Liberal Democratic Party members with seats in parliament, the Asahi said. I was already 99% on hime but update now to 100% https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/japan-yoshihide-suga-in-pole-position-for-pm-as-debate-kicks-off/story-4M3r7KLtLElCi8ZGmbcyXL.html

As @ashalom pointed out, Suga now has 58% of total LDP votes, even without counting 141 votes (coming from party prefecture chapters), thus it is more than 99.5% sure that he will become the next leader. We round this up to 100%.
Source:
https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/japan-yoshihide-suga-in-pole-position-for-pm-as-debate-kicks-off/story-4M3r7KLtLElCi8ZGmbcyXL.html
Updated with latest news showing Suga greatly leading in polls.

Really looks like Suga has it in the bag... from the Economist:
“The three men vying to succeed Abe Shinzo as leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, and hence as Japan’s prime minister, held the first of two debates today, before Monday’s vote. Mr Abe is stepping down after almost eight years in office, because of ill health. Their platforms are not vastly different. Suga Yoshihide, Mr Abe’s 71-year-old loyal chief cabinet secretary, Ishiba Shigeru, 63, a hawkish ex-minister of defence and agriculture (and Mr Abe’s sole competitor in the 2018 election to be party leader), and Kishida Fumio, also 63, a liberal former foreign minister who is now the LDP’s policy chief, all want to change Japan’s constitution, ensure a free and open Indo-Pacific region and revitalise rural areas. The debates will not change much. Only 141 of the 535 votes come from rank-and-file party members. Mr Suga has already secured the backing of five of the LDP’s seven factions, which will cast the other 394.“

While public opinion polls  favor Ishiba over Suga, the elections will be conducted by other delegates, who strongly favor Suga. There still are two debates to be had, so I keep room for the possibility of some outperformance despite the strong tilt towards Ishiba
My current model has Ishiba below 0.5% so have rounded down
Given we are getting close to Sept 14 and Yoshihide Suga's popularity is rising  https://time.com/5886682/japan-shinzo-abe-yoshihide-suga/

Updated 20200908

As @pchi notes, Suga effectively has explicit support from 264 out of 535 of the LDP members. This is a significant lead over the other candidates, and is already almost a majority. There is always room for the unexpected in the political world, so I still place a 2% chance that something goes wrong with Suga's candidacy and the candidate currently in second place (Ishiba) is elected.

First of all, it's important to note that the decision for the next leader of the LDP will be decided on September 14.  From recent pull forecasts it seems that Yoshihide Suga has taken a pretty clear lead in terms of gaining favorable support from the 535 LDP members that will be choosing Shinzo Abe's successor. According to Financial Times, Suga has already received endorsements from 4 out of the 5 largest party factions in Japan (https://www.ft.com/content/c0022119-366b-4212-a1cc-2625e2ce5125). This means that 264 members (representing the factions) have already expressed support for Suga.  I keep a small waiting for Ishiba as he had used to be the front runner as Abe's successor, but his decline was mainly met by unpopularity within other LDP leaders. @hermannviktor has also given substantial polling evidence to support the likelihood of Suga being the successor.

Of the five candidates, 2 are not planning to run (Aso and Kono). As @hermannviktor mentioned, the three latest polls suggest strong popular support behind Suga (38%) compared to Ishiba (25%)  and Kishida (5%). Nonetheless, the next leader will be chosen by a vote by the Diet, not a popular vote. The winner is decided by a majority vote; specifically there are 535 ballots = 141 reps from prefectures + 394 Diet members. Again as @hermannviktor mentioned, the initial amount of endorsements Suga has as well as the split of the factional support behind each candidate suggests Suga has a comfortable lead over his competitors, with Ishiba tailing.
Suga ahead in the (favorability) polls now; I'm almost at 100%.

Current situation: Japan’s ruling party will choose Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s successor on Sept 14 after Abe abruptly announced his resignation for health reasons on Friday August 28th. Mr Abe has so far declined to name a favorite candidate, saying that the leading ones were all “very promising”.  Base rate: polls Mr Suga emerged as the front-runner to replace Prime Minister Shinzo Abe this week after securing the backing of several of his party’s key factions. Suga has 38% of the public’s support, ahead of 25% for former Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba who had previously led several media opinion polls. Fumio Kishida, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party’s policy chief, came in last with 5%.  Specific case considerations:
- Mr Suga 71, is Mr Abe’s chief cabinet secretary and a leading candidate to replace him. Given positive view on Abe’s action: 71 percent of the poll respondents gave positive evaluations—17 percent said “very high” and 54 percent picked “fairly high”—for the policies of the second Abe administration, that is a +. 
- Main concurrent is Mr. Ishiba, 63, is an abrasive former defense minister who twice ran against Mr. Abe for the party leadership. However, the elected candidate will have the obligation to further Mr. Abe’s policy goals until September 2021. Those to do so are those close to the power -> Ishiba is not 
- highly institutionalized factions that structure the vote and the few remaining days to the elections -> give much more weight to last poll than previous one that gave more chance to Ishiba [1] https://nationalpost.com/pmn/news-pmn/japans-suga-jumps-in-popularity-tops-favourability-poll-for-next-pm/wcm/9263ce5d-f01b-4aec-8b9f-e8f0fed34274/

As Alex has mentioned, Japan votes heavily along faction lines, and all major factions support Suga. I will price in a tail for the other main candidate, Ishiba, in case their factions have significant deviations.

Their chances are slim albeit one of Abe's policies was to promote women in polictics.

We know that the elections for the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party will be held on Monday, September 14. Initial scheduling was September 2021, however, incumbent party president (and longest-serving) Prime Minister Shinzo Abe resigned on August 28, 2020 due to health concerns.
Initial candidate responses:
Taro Aso declined the candidacy, thus it is virtually 0% probable that he would run for the position.
Taro Kono declined the candidacy, thus it is virtually 0% probable that he would run for the position. Current polls:
There were 3 polls conducted on this matter and in the latest poll (done by Asahi Shimbun) on September 2-3, Yoshihide Suga was the major candidate for the election with 38% of the people questioned voting for Mr. Suga (vs 25% for Mr. Ishiba and 5% for Mr. Kishida and 26% undecided).
There were 2 other polls done on August 29-30 with Mr. Ishiba as great favorite, however at this time Mr. Ishiba has not announced his candidacy yet. Endorsements:
So far 5 National Diet members have given endorsements and all of these endorsements were for Mr. Suga. This is important because the LDP lawmaker decided that vote will be restricted to the Diet members and representatives from each of Japan's 47 prefectures. Therefore, Mr. Suga having 5 endorsements already (from possible competitors) and the other candidates having none is a very strong indication of the current environment (https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20200831/p2g/00m/0na/125000c). News coverage:
News coverage has been very in favor of Mr. Suga with the other candidates receiving less spotlight and Mr. Kishida being slammed due to a smaller scandal (https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3099933/japan-pm-hopeful-kishida-slammed-over-wife-maid-twitter-photo)

Several different news articles from several different sources indicate favoritism in Suga and negative views in Ishiba. Suga currently has endorsement from 4/5 parties. With 2 months left, it would take a large 3 sigma event for one of these parties to reverse their opinion. Although acknowledge that party opinion reversal is correlated . I also considered the fact that factions dont always vote in line but multiple sources indicate they would in this case.

I had held out 2% for Kishida, but the sentiment in the news seems to be turning strongly against him (https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3099933/japan-pm-hopeful-kishida-slammed-over-wife-maid-twitter-photo). Taking this into account, the consensus seems to be unquestionably that Suga will have a successful bid.

The next leader will be chosen by an LDP vote (not public). 
Suga seems to be leading forecasts and climbing ahead of election, and seems to have garnered Abe's support. Kono and Aso likely not running. Kishida is not very popular in public polls, and thus doesn't seem like he will be chosen. Ishiba seems to be running 2nd place, but he's not very popular with party leadership and thus I don't think he will be chosen.

Taro Aso and Taro Kono both declined: 0%. Winner requires majority of 535 ballots from among 394 Diet members and 141 representatives from across the country's 47 prefectures. Diet is dominated by factional allegiances. So far votes that are reported to support each faction:
SUGA: Hosoda (98) + Aso (54) + Ishihara (11)
KISHIDA: Kishida (47)
ISHIBA: Ishiba (19)
Undecided: Takeshita (54), Nikai (47), non-affiliated (64) 141 regional reps: Ishiba is very popular with populace- came in first in recent Nikkei / TV Tokyo poll (28% support). Suga was in 4th place at 11%, with Kishida dead last. Even pessimistically, we assign 2/3 of the regional reps to Ishiba and split the remainder between Suga / Kishida. This leaves us with the totals:
SUGA: 186
ISHIBA: 113
KISHIDA: 71 Suga has a very comfortable lead and will likely get more non-affiliated support; Ishiba is runner-up but is reported to be unpopular with Diet members (JapanTimes article); suggests his votecount won't increase by much. Overall, Suga is clear favorite but probably overestimating his lead- risks from potential dark horse candidate declaring (very unlikely) or unexpected shift in faction allegiances.
Further to my forecast of 20200902, it looks like Suga has the nomination in the bag ahead of the election in 41 days time - https://reut.rs/3hWXzv0
Go for broke, Suga has been a solid communicator for Abe for seven years, he knows the game plan and is respected.
Surprised by crowd forecast of Suga 86%. Do agree, seems like he has a lock on it, however...
Sounds like he already has the votes he needs. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-02/suga-expected-to-formalize-bid-for-japan-prime-minister-s-job

Some possibilities: Yoshihide Suga to take the top spot, with Fumio Kishida to take a defence-ministership or smth. Alternatively, Fumio Kishida to take the top spot with Ishiba to take a decent cabinet post. Alternatively, Suga as top spot with Ishiba in a cabinet position. Rock beats scissors beats paper beats rock.   Also, surely the option of a compromise candidate / someone else is not 0%.  Also, Suga probably getting a boost from the announcement, which might dim.
Based solely upon LDP Faction representation between possibl candidates
Updated to stronger support for Suga.

NHK World "Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga Yoshihide appears to be solidifying support among lawmakers of the main governing Liberal Democratic Party as the successor to Prime Minister Abe Shinzo."

https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/japans-mr-fixit-yoshihide-suga-set-to-succeed-shinzo-abe-as-leader/2020/09/01/28addb02-eb60-11ea-bd08-1b10132b458f_story.html +10% bump for Suga given this article.

Aso isn't running and his faction supports Suga. It sounds like the rural districts who generally support Ishiba receive a lower proportion of the vote. Suga appears to have the most support. Low confidence because I'm not familiar with Japan and it's possible the rest put their support behind Ishiba. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-08-31/in-race-for-power-in-japan-election-rules-are-half-the-battle https://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/en/news/20200901_44/ https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-politics-faction-idUSKBN25R0PL

TOKYO (Reuters) - Japan’s top government spokesman, Yoshihide Suga, moved a step closer to becoming the next premier after the ruling party decided on Tuesday on a slimmed-down leadership vote that favours the long-time lieutenant of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. Suga has also won the backing of the largest faction of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), media reported, making him a strong front-runner to replace Abe, who announced on Friday he was stepping down for health reasons. Suga has not announced his candidacy for leader of the LDP but has indicated privately that he intends to run, a source told Reuters. Source: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-politics-idUSKBN25R31K

According to the commentary on Japanese politics, the leadership of the LDP does not concern itself with Policy or Public popularity, but the support from the factions that hope to garner ministerial positions in the cabinet.
Yoshihide Suga was before considered a continual No. 2 but seems to have gathered support from the Nikai and Hosoda factions and seen as a safe pair of hands continuing the stability of the Abe period of government.
Shigeru Ishiba and Taro Kono are more popular with the public, but do not have the factional numbers.
Kishida Fumio is Abe’s  favourite. https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2020/08/31/commentary/japan-commentary/shinzo-abe-successor-ldp-election/  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/08/polls-show-japan-defence-minister-popular-pm-200831021143017.html  https://www.economist.com/asia/2020/08/29/who-will-replace-abe-shinzo-after-his-resignation-owing-to-illness  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/31/japans-next-prime-minister-faces-a-difficult-year-ahead-after-abe-resigns.html
https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/Japan-after-Abe/Abe-lieutenant-Suga-enters-Japan-prime-minister-race  https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2019/07/30/commentary/japan-commentary/factional-politics-remain-force-japan/

Suga already holds a lot of power as Chief Cabinet Secretary, very close to Abe
Kishida is former foreign minister, loyal to Abe and even from same region of Japan
Ishiba former defense minister who's run aggressive campaigns against Abe for party leadership in the past
Motegi is foreign minister, has run Abenomics program for years, not in Abe's party faction though (could be a compromise candidate)
Kono is current defense minister and former foreign minister, much more liberal, bit of a "lone wolf"
Aso deputy prime minister and former PM, old news though and sometimes says the wrong thing publicly (like some nazi comments), could be an intermediate person to carry the torch until a proper election in 2021 Most popular choice among public is Ishiba (34%), but lacks support from inside party. Next most popular is Suga (14%), Kishida is in last place as he's not that charismatic Suga looks like the favorite as he's very politically connected already, close to Abe, and holds the highest populace opinion of all the insiders
Ishiba and Kishida are toss-ups depending on whether the party goes with the populace favorite, or very-inside party Abe-favorite who will maintain the status quo
Kono and Aso are low maybe's because they're far outsiders, either for a liberal-first foreign policy focus hail mary or a lets-do-nothing hold the line vote
No one else is talking about anyone else, and its an inside party vote in 2 weeks, so very unlikely to be anyone else
lots of japanese prime ministers were chief cabinet secretaries before that. examples would be abe, abes successor in 2007 fukuda, primeministers miyazawa and obuchi.

From NHK Aug 30 "But they concurred that this time a faster option should be taken to avoid any political vacuum. They will ask only LDP Diet lawmakers and representatives of prefectural chapters to cast votes.
Party factions have not forwarded any candidates so far, and have been closely watching each other.
Candidates could begin their activities in earnest after Tuesday, when the ruling party will decide when and how the next leader will be chosen."

Members of Nippon Kaigi. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Members_of_Nippon_Kaigi
Taro Aso: Yes.
Shigeru Ishiba: Yes
Fumio Kishida: Yes
Taro Kono: No.
Yoshihide Suga: Yes

The LDP has been the most prominent political party in Japan since 1945. It is worth noting that Abe has been president of the LDP for an incredibly long time - almost 8 years when compared to the 2-3 years average time in office, so the internal geometries might have shifted since the last election. Anyway, presuming nothing changed, Shigeru Ishiba has been the strongest opponent in 2012 and 2018, even though his extreme positions (he is affiliated to the openly nationalist organization Nippon-Kaigi and the attempted formation of an opposing faction within the LDP) might encourage the rest of the party to join forces to promote a single opponent. Among the options, Taro Aso is maybe too old to take office, so Fumio Kishida or Taro Kono might have a stronger chance. Yoshihide Suga might be a wild card as he has been a close ally of  Abe and has pushed for economic instead of constitutional reforms (typically art. 9, about the prohibition of reforming a Japanese army), but openly denied interest in the position, which lowers expectations. Finally Toshimitsu Motegi - not listed - is unlikely to win, because of recent scandals (possible breach of Japan's electoral laws in 2018). This brings me to express a significant advantage for Kishida.

Updating to harmonize with the NYT article. From Aug 29 NYT "Those who have already announced their desire to stand for prime minister include Fumio Kishida, a former foreign minister; Toshimitsu Motegi, the current foreign minister; Taro Kono, the defense minister; Shigeru Ishiba, a former defense minister who once ran against Mr. Abe for party leader; Seiko Noda, a member of the lower house of Parliament; and Tomomi Inada, another former defense minister."
Unclear why Taro Kono so low.

Perhaps a little more on the Suga side of the ledger...  tough one to gauge as not sure what LDP wants (continuation of Abe policies, Abe-light, or different direction). For a guy who doesn’t want the job, Suga sure is giving a lot of interviews. I am curious about Kono given China and Trump with a slightly increased focus on military.

https://www.dw.com/en/shinzo-abes-departure-signals-the-end-of-an-era-in-tokyo/a-54738816

https://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/a06203/who-will-succeed-prime-minister-abe-introducing-the-candidates.html Taro Aso: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance Asō Tarō, a staunch Abe ally. Asō, who served as prime minister himself (2008–9), was formerly a key member of the Taiyūkai faction led by Kōno’s father, Yōhei, who served as foreign minister, LDP president, and speaker of the House of Representatives... Ishiba Shigeru: Political Heavyweight Ishiba Shigeru: A more traditional candidate is 61-year-old Ishiba Shigeru (eleventh-term lower house member). Ishiba is the leader of his own faction, albeit a small one (numbering just 20 members) and has held several cabinet posts. Stressing his policy experience and expertise in national security, having led the Defense Agency and later the Ministry of Defense, Ishiba is calling for a wholesale revision of the Constitution’s war-renouncing Article 9. Kishida Fumio: 61-year-old Kishida Fumio (ninth-term lower house member), currently chairman of the LDP’s Policy Research Council. Kishida’s faction claims direct descent from the venerable Kōchikai, whence sprang many of Japan’s mainstream conservative leaders. While waiting patiently in the wings, Kishida has steadily lost political influence and momentum; in recent opinion polls he has slipped below both Koizumi and Ishiba as the LDP politician deemed best suited to take over the top spot. Taro Kono: Kōno Tarō belongs to the Shikōkai faction led by Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance Asō Tarō, a staunch Abe ally. Either Kōno and Katō could emerge as a strong candidate if anointed as Abe’s preferred successor, but neither has the power base needed to win a party election without the Abe camp’s whole-hearted support. Yoshihide Suga: Finally, 69-year-old Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga Yoshihide (eighth-term lower house member) has attracted growing interest as a possible contender—despite repeated denials by Suga himself. Born on a farm in Akita Prefecture, Suga worked his way through Hōsei University in Tokyo, worked as a secretary to a Diet member and a cabinet minister, and served in the Yokohama City Council before winning election to the Diet in 1996. A master of crisis management and policy negotiations, he mentors a group of about 40 young Diet politicians. Although Suga has consistently ruled out a bid for the top LDP post, the pundits are not prepared to count him out just yet. Someone else / Long-shots.
- (Koizumi "His father is former Prime Minister" Shinjirō): 37-year-old Koizumi Shinjirō, a mere stripling by traditional LDP standards. Koizumi is a House of Representatives member in his fourth term, with no cabinet experience and no faction behind him. Yet in recent opinion polls, respondents have placed him up alongside former LDP Secretary General Ishiba Shigeru as the most suitable successor to Abe as prime minister.What Koizumi lacks in seniority, some might argue, he makes up for in pedigree. His father is former Prime Minister Koizumi Jun'ichirō, who remained in office more than five and a half years (2001–6), thanks to an unusually high public approval rating. His grandfather, Koizumi Jun’ya, served as director general of the Japan Defense Agency in the 1960s, and his great grandfather, Koizumi Matajirō, was a communications minister (known for his colorful speeches and dragon tattoo) before World War II. In this sense, Koizumi certainly fits the profile of a “hereditary” LDP politician. But more than his background, it is his mediagenic good looks, public-speaking skills, and memorable sound bites that have propelled him into the national spotlight at so young an age.This is not to suggest that the young Koizumi lacks substance. As director of the agriculture division of the LDP Policy Research Council, he has helped spearhead bold reforms, including measures to curtail the influence of the Japan Agriculture Group over the farming industry and government policy. As de facto leader of a group of young LDP lawmakers dedicated to social security reform and fiscal rehabilitation, he has called for free daycare and early-childhood education through a system of “children’s insurance,” paid for by contributions from employers and workers. - (Katō Katsunobu): Katō is more aptly viewed as a member of Abe’s inner circle. A close confidant and longtime supporter, he remained steadfastly loyal even after Abe stepped down as prime minister in 2007. After Abe led the LDP back to power in 2012, Katō was awarded a succession of cabinet posts—deputy chief cabinet secretary, minister for promoting dynamic engagement of all citizens, and minister of health, labor, and welfare—before being appointed chair of the LDP General Council.  - Noda Seiko: Another candidate who defies LDP stereotypes is 58-year-old Noda Seiko (ninth-term lower house member), former chair of the LDP General Council. Appointed minister of posts and telecommunications at the young age of 37, she is often mentioned as a likely candidate to become Japan’s first woman prime minister. She has previously steered clear of factional politics, but her lack of a strong base within the LDP doomed her previous two bids for the party’s top post. In 2015 and again in 2018, she announced plans to challenge Abe, arguing the need for open debate on the issues, but on both occasions she was forced to abandon her long-shot bid after failing to win the required endorsement of 20 LDP Diet members. Chastened by experience, she has since set about building a faction of her own ***
My own comments:
- Aso: It strikes me as somewhat unlikely that he will be prime minister a second time. Isn't liked by my Japanese friends.
- Ishiba: I thought that being against Article 9 was a big no-no.
- Kishida: Used to be powerful
- Kono: Possible successor.
- Suga: Isn't bidding. 
- Others: Seem long-shots.

Aso (deputy PM) if Abe incapacitated (unlikely). Ishiba = Abe critic. Kishida = continuation of Abe policies albeit more centrist (less right wing). Kono = defence minister (long shot ). Suga = cabinet secretary is just that, a bureaucrat. Toshimitsu = foreign minister as someone else but unlikely.
